_decoded_content.title: Running two taps/targets at the same time leads to an error when attempting to delete their config
_decoded_content.description:
If you run two taps at the same time you can hit this
`[WinError 2] The system cannot find the file specified: 'C:\\\\Users\\\\Derek\\\\Desktop\\\\code\\\\d11co\\\\meltano\\\\.meltano\\\\run\\\\tap-oracle\\\\tap.config.json`
Replication steps.
1. Run meltano invoke tap-name (proc1)
1. While that processes is running run meltano invoke tap-name (proc2)
1. When proc1 finishes everything will be ok (It'll delete tap.config.json)
1. When proc2 finishes meltano will attempt to remove tap.config.json and fail with this error
First time I've hit this, and it was only in DEV as I'm testing what will happen in a few different scenarios. Is this a bug or expected behavior?

Slack thread: https://meltano.slack.com/archives/C01TCRBBJD7/p1628168579093400

This was hard to debug for me because of #2881

_decoded_content.title: WinError 2 - Sent to STDOUT not STDERR
_decoded_content.description:
When this error is hit 
`[WinError 2] The system cannot find the file specified: 'C:\\\\Users\\\\Derek\\\\Desktop\\\\code\\\\d11co\\\\meltano\\\\.meltano\\\\run\\\\tap-powerschool\\\\tap.config.json`

This message is sent to STDOUT not STDERR. 

To replicate (at least on windows maybe it's on linux too, haven't checked)

1. Run meltano invoke tap-name (proc1)
1. While that processes is running run meltano invoke tap-name (proc2)
1. When proc1 finishes everything will be ok (It'll delete tap.config.json)
1. When proc2 finishes meltano will attempt to remove tap.config.json and fail with this error

Slack message: https://meltano.slack.com/archives/C01TCRBBJD7/p1628190374111300

Related slack message (Seperate issue #2882): https://meltano.slack.com/archives/C01TCRBBJD7/p1628168579093400

_decoded_content.title: `meltano invoke` should not always run `--discover` prior to running the provided arguments
_decoded_content.description:
This is taken from the following slack message https://meltano.slack.com/archives/C01TCRBBJD7/p1627054578178200

**Josh Lloyd**:
what is the expected behavior of `meltano invoke`? I’m trying to run a very specific command for a custom tap but the command seems to be ignoring the arguments I’m trying to pass to the tap. Specifically I’m trying to run `meltano invoke tap-rest-api --infer_schema` but the first line in the error message is
```
Catalog discovery failed: command ['/Users/.../meltano/.meltano/extractors/tap-rest-api/venv/bin/tap-rest-api', '--config', '/Users/.../meltano/.meltano/run/tap-rest-api/tap.config.json', '--discover'] returned 1: INFO Loading Schemas
```
which makes me think that it’s ignoring the argument --infer_schema entirely because I don’t see it in the command it’s spitting back at me. It seems to just be running --discover instead.

**Douwe Maan**:
@Josh Lloyd `meltano invoke` with a tap will always call the tap in discovery mode first if the `discovery` capability is present, except when `meltano invoke <tap> --discovery` is run directly, because discovery/catalog is needed for sync mode (without any `--` args). I think the better behavior would be to only run discovery mode ahead of the regular requested invocation if it’s actually running in sync mode, i.e. not getting any user-provided arguments. That would require changing [https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/master/src/meltano/core/plugin/singer/tap.py#L213](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/master/src/meltano/core/plugin/singer/tap.py#L213)

**Douwe Maan**: 
So to be clear, it’s not running `--discover` instead of `--infer_schema` , it’s running it before running `--infer_schema`, and if `--discover` fails, it won’t get to `--infer_schema`

**Douwe Maan**:
The easiest way to work around this would be to either make sure `--discover`  doesn’t fail (which may be impossible if that depends on having inferred the schema first?), removing the `discovery` capability (temporarily), or fixing [that check in](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/master/src/meltano/core/plugin/singer/tap.py#L213). I agree this is undesireable behavior ...

_decoded_content.title: Incomplete `settings` YAML causes `AttributeError: is_extra`
_decoded_content.description:
To replicate (Haven't tried this on linux yet, only on Windows) :
1. Use the meltano.yml below (This might happen on linux too, I'm not certain)
1. Run `meltano install`
1. Run `meltano invoke target-csv`

Crazy part:
1. Remove 
```
settings:
- name: sftp_password
- kind: password
```
2. Everything works fine


meltano.yml example failure.

```
version: 1
send_anonymous_usage_stats: true
project_id: 6a99b560-bf01-4224-a707-ca9a8c2be1aa
plugins:
  loaders:
  - name: target-csv
    namespace: target_csv
    pip_url: git+https://github.com/AutoIDM/target-csv@dev
    executable: target-csv
    settings:
    - name: sftp_password
    - kind: password
    capabilities:
    - state
    - catalog
    - discover
    - properties
```

_decoded_content.title: Stale jobs not failed automatically
_decoded_content.description:
### What is the current *bug* behavior?
I create a container that runs `meltano ui` as part of its entrypoint. In the pipelines screen, I see old jobs that never completed still "running." I have no ability to delete or stop these jobs (see attached image).


### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
According to [what I've read here](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/merge_requests/2000), I think the jobs should be marked as failed. But I would expect to be able to cancel them, regardless.

### Steps to reproduce
Run some pipelines, but destroy the container out from under the application, leaving them in a RUNNING state within the DB.
Re-create the container later (hours or days) and run the UI.
You see running pipelines that aren't really running.



### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

Here's a query on the `job` table:
```
meltano=> select id, run_id, state, started_at, ended_at, trigger, last_heartbeat_at from job where state ='RUNNING';

```

_decoded_content.title: Add a warning when both catalog and properties are specified in meltano.yml
_decoded_content.description:
I had a few different taps that were seemingly installed and set up correctly, but that weren't loading any data when run nor throwing any errors. Details of my debugging are in [this slack thread](https://meltano.slack.com/archives/C013EKWA2Q1/p1617041948136700), but as @DouweM generously helped me figure out, the root turned out to be that I had both catalog and properties set up as capabilities for these custom taps in meltano.yml, while these taps both only support properties currently. Removing catalog fixed the issue.

To that end, it'd be useful to have meltano throw a warning in situations where both catalog and properties are included as capabilities for custom taps.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description:
As a start, I think it would be good to prioritize based on:
- urgency of getting feedback
- relative implementation difficulty
- symbiotic relationships between issues

_decoded_content.title: Using redirection commands like > doesn't work with Meltano
_decoded_content.description: I was helping someone debug and discovered that redirecting the command line output to a file using `> tmp.txt` wasn't working as you'd expect. Some data would get written but it was just a subset of what was actually sent to the command line.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description:
As a start, I think it would be good to prioritize based on:
- urgency of getting feedback
- relative implementation difficulty
- symbiotic relationships between issues

_decoded_content.title: `pip_url: -e <path>` does not work with plugins that use pyproject.toml, like taps built using the SDK
_decoded_content.description:
As mentioned in https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2580, `pip` does not allow local installs to utilize [PEP-517](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0517/), which means that `pip_url: -e <path>` does not work with plugins that use `pyproject.toml` instead of `setup.py`. `pip_url: <path>` works, but that way the plugin isn't in [editable/development mode](https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/reference/pip_install/#install-editable).

Since the SDK's [cookiecutter template uses `pyproject.toml`](https://gitlab.com/meltano/singer-sdk/-/blob/development/cookiecutter/tap-template/%7B%7Bcookiecutter.library_name%7D%7D/pyproject.toml), this complicates development of taps using the SDK, since they cannot easily be tested with Meltano (`meltano invoke`, `meltano elt`) without constantly running `meltano install extractor <tap>` between changes.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description:
As a start, I think it would be good to prioritize based on:
- urgency of getting feedback
- relative implementation difficulty
- symbiotic relationships between issues

_decoded_content.title: add warn on meltano select when rules conflict
_decoded_content.description: Following from https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2638#note_528335663 there should be a warning when exclusion rules make inclusion rules moot. this could probably be extended to handle the opposite case as well.

_decoded_content.description: Following from https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2638#note_528335663 there should be a way to remove rules using `meltano select`.

_decoded_content.title: Handle deprecated --properties flag
_decoded_content.description:
`--properties` is a deprecated flag that _seems_ to work the same as --catalog, i.e. it would work with the same file. 

https://github.com/singer-io/tap-hubspot/issues/84 is an example of a tap that hasn't deprecated it. 

We could handle this behind the scenes or enable users to override it somehow.

- urgency of getting feedback
- relative implementation difficulty
- symbiotic relationships between issues

_decoded_content.title: Meltano should validate ability to write to loader at elt invocation
_decoded_content.description:
In testing `tap-gitlab` and `tap-zendesk` the extraction failed because there was a problem while loading data (`target-snowflake`).

In my specific case, the target was expecting the schema to already exist in Snowflake. The full extract would run a number of API calls and then when it tried to load it would bomb out without a clear way to retry with the data already "extracted".

Having a validation step that happens invisibly when you invoked `elt` would be good. Or we could have a separate `meltano validate` step. 

Thoughts @meltano/core-team ?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description:
As a start, I think it would be good to prioritize based on:
- urgency of getting feedback
- relative implementation difficulty
- symbiotic relationships between issues

_decoded_content.title: Empty projects cause extract failure
_decoded_content.description:
While testing in https://gitlab.com/meltano/meta/-/issues/4, I found that if a project is empty (no commits) that the extract will fail with:

> CRITICAL Error making request to GitLab API: GET https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/24722673/repository/commits?since=2020-05-01T00:00:00Z&with_stats=true&page=1&per_page=100 [404 - b'{"message":"404 Repository Not Found"}']

I would expect this to be a silent "failure".

_decoded_content.title: Add `meltano config <plugin> test` to test connection
_decoded_content.description:
The "Test Connection" button in the UI tests an extractor by running it and seeing if it outputs any `RECORD` messages: https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/85e1b339e35d7094b48cc73b25195479c890d57e/src/meltano/api/controllers/orchestrations.py#L371

The new command could do the same thing, unless extractor or loader has the `test` capability and implements its own testing logic: https://gitlab.com/meltano/singer-sdk/-/issues/14

_decoded_content.title: Add command to reset state for a Job ID/schedule
_decoded_content.description:
When using an orchestrator to run pipelines on a schedule, it may be more practical to say "do a full refresh on the next run" by resetting the incremental replication state, and then leaving it to the orchestrator to perform the next run when appropriate, than it is to explicitly do a full refresh by manually logging into the environment and using the `--full-refresh` flag on `meltano elt` or `meltano schedule run`.

We could realize this by inserting a new row into the `job` table without state that will still be taken into account when the next run tries to determine the latest state, but it may be odd to have `job` rows that don't actually correspond to runs, especially when we start listing runs in the UI and CLI: https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2567

Another option would be to flip a flag on the most recent run record to say its state should be ignored, so that we don't end up with extra "fake" runs.

Since this should work for all Job IDs, not just those that have a corresponding schedule, `meltano reset(-state) <job_id>` would be more appropriate than `meltano schedule reset(-state) <schedule>`, although I don't love how it looks.

Since we have `--dump=state` on `meltano elt` and `meltano schedule run`, it may make sense to add `meltano state <job_id>` (to dump) and `meltano state <job_id> reset`, like we have `meltano config <plugin>` (to dump) and `meltano config <plugin> reset`.

_decoded_content.title: When target process fails, `meltano elt` may report `ConnectionResetError` or `BrokenPipeError` error instead of loader failure
_decoded_content.description:
As reported by @cooley1 [on Slack](https://meltano.slack.com/archives/CFG3C3C66/p1611076265035100?thread_ts=1610560265.206500&cid=CFG3C3C66):

When the target process dies (because of an error or being killed by the OS) and its stdin stream is closed, the [`capture_subprocess_output(p_tap.stdout, p_target.stdin)`](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/91bdd3d7e7c6b8e8965cbed91aa16cce0ac6ec77/src/meltano/core/runner/singer.py#L119) call that's responsible for forwarding tap output to the target may encounter a `BrokenPipeError` in [`writer.write(line)`](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/91bdd3d7e7c6b8e8965cbed91aa16cce0ac6ec77/src/meltano/core/logging/utils.py#L71) or a `ConnectionResetError` in [`await writer.drain()`](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/91bdd3d7e7c6b8e8965cbed91aa16cce0ac6ec77/src/meltano/core/logging/utils.py#L72) _before_ [`p_target.wait()`](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/91bdd3d7e7c6b8e8965cbed91aa16cce0ac6ec77/src/meltano/core/runner/singer.py#L139) realizes that the target has quit, resulting in the [exception being re-raised](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/91bdd3d7e7c6b8e8965cbed91aa16cce0ac6ec77/src/meltano/core/runner/singer.py#L178) immediately and reported to the user, instead of the [target's remaining output being processed](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/91bdd3d7e7c6b8e8965cbed91aa16cce0ac6ec77/src/meltano/core/runner/singer.py#L204) and the [target's failure being reported](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/91bdd3d7e7c6b8e8965cbed91aa16cce0ac6ec77/src/meltano/core/runner/singer.py#L229) as the reason `meltano elt` failed.

`capture_subprocess_output` may need to rescue these `ConnectionResetError` or `BrokenPipeError` errors and finish silently, so that `p_target.wait()` gets a chance to realize that the process died, which we would then handle as appropriate.

Alternatively, we could explicitly detect when `capture_subprocess_output(p_tap.stdout, p_target.stdin)` raises  `ConnectionResetError` or `BrokenPipeError`, deduce that this means that `p_target.stdin` is closed, and handle this just like we would `p_target` dying.

_decoded_content.title: Monitor tap and target process memory usage and warn when limit is exceeded
_decoded_content.description:
### Problem to solve
(Summarize the problem we are trying to solve in the form of we need to do [A], so that [B] can [C])


### Target audience
(For whom are we doing this? Include a persona)


### Further details
cf post in Slack: https://meltano.slack.com/archives/C013EKWA2Q1/p1610642250000700?thread_ts=1608595339.296300&cid=C013EKWA2Q1

Tap-zendesk was using a lot of memory and it got killed with `-9`. It was very hard to debug since the only error message received was `ELT could not be completed: Tap failed`.



### Proposal
Would be great to receive a warning if/when a memory limit is exceeded


### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?
Receive a warning because the job is killed due to a tap/target using too much memory.

### Regression test
(Ensure the feature doesn't cause any regressions)
- [ ] Write adequate test cases and submit test results
- [ ] Test results should be reviewed by a person from the team

_decoded_content.title: Warn if tap that uses `ACTIVATE_VERSION` is used with target that doesn't support it
_decoded_content.description:
`ACTIVATE_VERSION` is an experimental and mostly-undocumented Singer feature that is nonetheless used/supported by a few popular taps and targets: https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2508

If a target doesn't understand the `ACTIVATE_VERSION` messages output by a tap, it may error out, or silently ignore the message and end up with duplicated records. We can help the user debug this.

This will require us to start tracking in `discovery.yml` whether taps and targets support this feature.

_decoded_content.title: Warn/fail when incremental replication is used with a target that appends instead of upserts
_decoded_content.description:
As I wrote [in Slack](https://meltano.slack.com/archives/CFG3C3C66/p1602609468175400?thread_ts=1602522150.168400&cid=CFG3C3C66) in response to the conversation that led to the creation of https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2504:

>>>
Meltano should warn users when they attempt to use incremental replication with a target that doesn't actually support it correctly, which starts with specifying in our discoverable plugin definitions (https://meltano.com/docs/contributor-guide.html#discoverable-plugins) whether a target supports incremental replication. 

Meltano would then detect whether incremental replication is used (read: whether we're passing a state file to the tap) and fail hard if the target doesn't support it, and suggest the user use full-table replication instead, or a different target. 

Meltano could also detect this and simply fall back on full-table replication, although this wouldn't actually be better with append-only formats like CSV and JSONL, or targets that wouldn't wipe the existing data before inserting new records. 

Some targets support `ACTIVATE_VERSION` (https://meltano.slack.com/archives/CFG3C3C66/p1601148878022700?thread_ts=1600699540.015800&cid=CFG3C3C66) which we may also be able to pay special consideration to.
>>>

This requires us to not just document which targets append instead of upsert (https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2505), but also track this in `discover.yml`: https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2507
